review_title: Jetstar Asia does not appreciate pilots.
pros: Elaborate corporate policies with Qantas DNA.
cons:
Management and all office workers back on full salaries since December 2021 while pilots are earning less than 50% of original contracted salaries until at least June 2022.
Pilot base salaries below 50% of pre-covid salaries for more than 18 months and to continue until at least end of June 2022 this having forced many pilots to have to do secondary jobs much to the risk of jeopardizing safety when having flying duties.
All other monetary benefits still on hold until at least end of June 2022.
More than 35% of total pilot group still furloughed with little to no guidance on when they might return to work even though there is not enough aircraft to support the entire pilot group- only 7 aircraft remain in Singapore which require approx 70 pilots while the total pilot group count approx 120 pilots.
Management expected to force new lower paid permanent contracts into effect for all pilots and all negotiations about contract terms are happening at executive level without any pilot group involvement.
Management seem unwilling to accept pilots unionizing.
Despite the current lower utilization of the aircraft, management has decided that night flights are still reasonable and sensible to operate while the added stressors is wholly on the crew who must operate such unwanted flights- known detrimental end of duty timings are 0400am and 0800am while having reported well before midnight.
The management is using maximum internal propaganda efforts through monthly and weekly newsletters as well as occasional video broadcasts in an attempt to indicate that the workers are happy and that it is a functional business however the morale has never been lower and most pilots are just waiting for opportunities to leave the company.

pros:
I have been working for Jetstar Airways for a little over 16 years now. After falling in love with the job for over a decade, I am 100% ready to make a career change. It is fast-paced (which i like), insanely busy, and no flights are the same.

Jetstar Airways also offer great benefits for employees including their families, paid training, health, life and long-term disability insurance. We also receive discounts on flight travels, hospitality services like hotels & rental of vehicles.
cons: Timezones and jet lag will play a mean number. This is unavoidable and one of the biggest downsides to working as a flight attendant. I find jetlag to be hell. I went through periods during my commercial aviation career where i was so fatigued that i could not sleep for more than two hours at a time.

pros: Great working environment to work in.
cons: Staff benefits may not be comparable.

pros:
Jetstar is an exciting place to work with every day being different. It's an interesting industry and covers a large array from flight operations to engineering to digital experience to safety. The business is complex but fascinating to learn.

It has a great culture and the people come together to deliver what the business needs in an agile manner. It's a much more flexible business than it's big sister, Qantas, but be prepared to achieve much with little funding.

There are good opportunities to grow and move within the business. Particularly with COVID-19 impacts the organisation has had to change to survive and that has opened new opportunities.

Some of the best coffee in Melbourne can be found within 5 minute walk in any direction!
cons:
As the company has moved from smaller "just get things done" startup to an actual enterprise it is struggling to define itself and the necessary processes.

Technology stack is aging and requires strong vision and disciplined delivery. It's unclear if current management have the capability to deliver this though.

Significantly impacted by COVID-19 and will be for some time to come, leading to uncertain full time work

Too many people empire-building rather than looking at the bigger picture

Be prepared to drop what you're working on, the focus changes so quickly there's a high probability you'll never see your work to completion.

pros: Great perks, passionate team, get along with everyone.
cons: Budget and capacity, some Politics from higher management.

pros:
The shifts are flexible and can be swapped. When times are busy even if you are rostering on for 4 hours you can often extend your shifts
Some of the customers are nice and you meet some interesting characters
cons:
- shifts can be swapped if somebody wants them! Otherwise every week is different and it’s hard to plan anything
- you don’t get to chose when you can take leave!!!! Oh yes - you bid (yes bid )to use your own leave like it’s a privilege and then get offered something you didn’t ask for it’s awful.
- managers are generally rude and nobody cares about you or will take the time to learn your name.
- the customers are mostly angry and rude. They don’t understand rock bottom prices equals delays/ cancellations and queues. 
- don’t be lured in by staff discounts- you only get standby travel and often don’t get on overbooked flights- and good luck getting the leave approved!

permitted to select am or pm shifts and generally pretty reliable. After all it was a casual job.
I would recommend this for anyone wanting to start out in the aviation sector as a stepping stone.
cons:
no annual leave or sick leave though a certificate was required for absences (as most labour hire companies expect)
Some people have very negative attitudes towards customers, shame when they are your business.

review_title: Awesome Place to work and make a difference to travellers
pros:
Inclusive and Diverse

Cross-functional work is encouraged in most areas

Individuals are encouraged to innovate

Great Travel Perks

Strong corporate culture (clear values, ideals you can get on board with)
cons:
Pays slightly below average, though perks make up for it if you use them right

HO is in Collingwood which is neither near an airport, nor in the CBD

Some teams were rife with empire building, in-fighting and micro-management. If you're looking to work at Jetstar in the digital space you would want to make sure you are comfortable with your hiring manager and ask something like "tell me about the most successful person you hired and what they did that you liked?" as it may be telling.

pros: Great work environment, with great travel perks. Culture was fun and and inclusive. Overall a good bunch of people to work with who didn't take themselves too seriously but knew how to knuckle down when required
cons: The constant cost pressures made it feel like you were on a constant hamster wheel trying to keep up with what management deemed to be a priority this week. New processes implemented with little direction about how they would work, and sometimes poor communication from leadership about big changes that would be affecting staff. Constant meddling by Qantas trying to change the priorities of the Jetstar group to whatever they felt was important instead of letting Jetstar run as a seperate entity.

cons: Some Managers micro manage and don't allow people to do their jobs fully

pros: The organisation has good culture and a good team.
cons: Passengers can be very demanding and front line managers are not well versed in HR issues.

review_title: Terrible management, incompetent workforce planning, job allocation
pros: Staff travel and other benefits from Qantas
cons: Roster, difficult to to apply for annual leave

pros:
Staff travel discount
Flexible working arrangement
Great team culture
I was blessed to work with an supportive manager
cons:
Poor annual incentive
Off site parking is expensive.

pros: Great 'can-do' culture, very friendly office environment
cons: Very lean cost on IT and harware

review_title: High pressure and never a dull moment
pros:
Discounted flights are a positive 
Linked to Qantas A renowned co
cons: No team environment - selfish people

pros: Career progression and opportunities, people.
cons: Salary progression, high workload, lean operation

pros: Flat hierarchy and management interacts well with staff
cons: unable to get season parking for staff

pros: Stable employment working with a professional team
cons: Disconnection between management and workers.

pros:
Overall I really did enjoyed being a flight attendant. 
I was on a casual contract which gave me more flexiblilty to pick up/ or easily get rid of shifts. 
Everyday is different which makes the job more interesting. 
Working for Jetstar is a good foot in the door to persue in your dreams of being a flight attendant.
cons:
It can be very exhausting and colleagues can be very nasty. It sometimes felt like I was back at high school with all the drama. 
No penalty rates for working on public holidays. 
You don’t get paid for doing ground school (4-5 weeks)

review_title: You may enjoy it for the first few
pros: Flat org structure (at least was when I left), engaged peers, travel benefits, compensation is generally fairly aligned with the market
cons: Started off as an amazing place to work where everyone was committed, and decisions were quick - we were in charge of our own destiny; not anymore. Things can be slow to move, especially where the decisions involve engagement with the mothership. Worse still, progression path is not well defined, and favors 'positioning' more than the actual performance. Other reviews are right in saying there is no real org culture

review_title: A very dynamic and reactive work environment. Things are constantly changing in the aviation world.
pros: Great people as every day colleagues, other cabin crew and pilots. Tight knit teams with high levels of trust. Attractive staff travel incentives. Working for a successful, growing and safe brand.
cons:
Always changing, very reactive industry in general. 
High turnover of middle  management to bigger airlines so alot of old ideas come round again. Management out of touch with the realities of front line positions.
The eternal struggle for market share means constant cost cutting and more pressures in front line crew. Yet we still have to smile and give million dollar service on our 4th flight on day 6 after a 3am start and 10hrs between shifts. Not the glamorous position assumed.

pros:
Good wage, ability for overtime and penalty rates
Ability to fly international and or domestic 
Left to your own devices most days, autonomy 
staff travel
cons:
hours and working conditions are not flexible. Once you have a family most people are required to leave as there is no concessions for mothers, no set days, no maximum hours required to work 
Most progression is sourced externally usually by people who only use it to get a foot in the door for internal progression to QANTAS
payroll is a nightmare, pays are never correct, overtime and day off payments are not paid you usually need to fight for months back and forth with management and payroll to receive benefits owed

pros: Foot in the door
cons: I was disappointed on how we were treated as the 'new crew' we were hired as casual and I didnt at all feel welcomed by the others. The company don't care about service they don't care about your duty if care of your well being if they are then everyone talks about it so no there's confidentiality at all. So disappointed. I then went to another airline and the culture was phenomenal. Jetstar experience was extremely a terrific experience but I learnt that that's what happens as a flight attendant you gotta have thick skin which I developed over time. Also no benefits for the full time casuals! Overall experience culture 1 star  company 1 star senior management zero star.. Sorry base managers!! You need to remember that once you were new true!

review_title: Great people but current senior management has no clue how to run this business.
pros: I did work here with great people and you learn to work with limited budgets and resources. Plenty of opportunities when you are just starting your career. Exciting environment.
cons: Current senior management has no idea how they have to run this business. They demonstrate a lack of strategic insight and operational knowledge and are causing a high turn-over. High level of burn out between the employees, most leave in their first or second year.

review_title: Challenging work, but lots of fun
pros: Work is always challenging and exciting so you're never bored. People are generally smart, motivated and hardworking so you have to keep up. If you like that style of work you'll find this a fun place to work. Small-ish company so lots of individual responsibility. Also, the opportunity to be a part of big projects. Staff travel benefits are great.
cons: Some growing pains as the company gets bigger (eg systems and processes need to be updated somewhat regularly). Dynamic industry so the environment is face paced and there is constant change. People who aren't comfortable with that tend to leave sooner rather than later. Big focus on low cost so you have to make do with very small budgets.

review_title: Please don't read this and think, oh it's just 1 person's opinion.
pros: Cheap staff fares but be warned - they're not guaranteed and you may have to say goodbye to your travel plans if someone buys a commercial ticket (ie not staff discounted) at the last minute.
cons:
- Toxic cliquey culture. There's the 'popular' crew, and then everyone else. So basically like high school.
- Does NOT care about employees at all. Not their careers, mental health, nothing. 
- Only cares about Revenue, Revenue, Revenue. Will give you X resources to deliver $5M in revenue. Next day, the target goes up to $10M because so-and-so underperformed this quarter, while resources remain at X if you're lucky. 
- Severe shiny ball syndrome - mostly in response to competitor activity/campaigns, rather than strategic changes in priorities
- Count tenure as dog years, you'll be worked to the bone.

pros: Fun work environment. Motivated, hard-working colleagues. Fast pace. Opportunities to contribute to cross-team projects and work on things that directly influence the direction the business takes. Work is always challenging (in a good way). Good pay. Smart leadership with a good applied business strategy.
cons: Can be stressful and the hours can be long. Very lean and low-cost way of working so you have to do the most amount of work possible with the fewest available resources. That's a good discipline to have, but it does add to the stress! Working here is fun and rewarding, but rarely is it easy :)

review_title: Great place to work with so many opportunities!!
pros: I have had so much exposure to so many different areas. I am able to make a lot of decisions, have autonomy in my role and have a Manager that trusts me.  I have never felt so empowered before.
cons: It's a very fast-paced environment and you will find there is a lot of challenges and obstacles to get through, however, you can use these situations to learn and grow in your professional career.

pros: Flexible hours as Casual/ easy to swap or give away shifts, possible to pick up extra shifts, Can stipulate if you prefer to work early or lates
cons: During very quiet months there is very little work, sometimes only 3 flying shifts in the one roster.  Pay is every 4 weeks, so after 2 weeks you are usually broke.  A lot of staff as Casuals have a second job

review_title: Great product, Aussie icon. People poorly led
pros:
Highly skilled and genuinely nice people to work with 
Aviation is fun and interesting
Learn some good business acumen as you are given a lot of responsibility
Exposure to Qantas head office
Working for an iconic Australian company you can be proud of
Chance to fly in business class is a treat as is the flexibility of taking staff cheap flights at short notice
cons:
Poor leadership and management of people at head office
Very low salary
Fast pace is not suited to everyone
Staff travel leaves you living life on stand by

review_title: Fun, exciting culture, but varies between departments
pros:
- Experiencing rapid growth so plenty of exciting projects
- Low cost airline = low resources, so a good opportunity to get involved in big projects
- Staff travel discount benefits and plenty of opportunities to travel
cons:
- Not consistent, management and experience differ greatly per department
- High turnover. Not currently seen as a long term career environment
- Not the best inter-department communication which means delays to project etc.

pros: The workplace culture is very positive and easy-going, and innovation is encouraged. the airline is growing and has formed a very stable business model. there are always opportunities to get involved in projects or to change positions. hard work is rewarded. the executive are very approachable and often visit the workforce
cons: The pay is lower than that of other airlines and we are sometimes under-resourced.

review_title: Spending roughly 60% of the time out of base
pros: One crew per one room at layover. Seniority is relatively low compared to other airlines in Asia. Promotion to the more senior position is not limited by age.
cons: Salary has become lower than it was a few years ago. Salary is relatively low considering that we spend most of the time in Australia.  Long work pattern up to 20+ days out of home base. Limited staff benefits compared to Australian based employees.

review_title: Great energy and people, could pay more
pros: Great people from all over the world. Fast paced environment and proactive energy to do things better. Amazing discounts on airlines all over the world and a real passion for travel shared by staff throughout the company.
cons: The salary could be better. Due to the pace it sometimes  felt like the work was churn and burn, as soon as a project was complete it was straight onto the next.

pros: Some very professional people; access to JAL's employee store and cafeteria; able to stay at Narita hotels cheaply
cons: Commuting costs on covered by the company; always fires to put out; long hours for certain people/functions; a few arrogant, powerful top-down types; long, expensive commutes if you live in Tokyo; employee flight pricing plans not so competitive relative to market price

pros: I really enjoyed the travel and the money was pretty good for a entry level position. Staff travel was also awesome!!
cons: Treated staff like crap at times, but you get that with larger companies. No incentives to work Christmas day etc. Work was my life!

pros: Most parts of the company are great - collaborative, fun, fast-paced and exciting place to be.  The work is interesting and challenging.
cons: Bullying and poor management behaviors are not addressed and harm the rest of the company

pros:
open to testing new ideas;
flexible when it comes to delivery and timeframes - managers do listen
good team spirit and culture
low on politics
cons:
start-up mentality  that doesn't fit with the size of company
architecture  input very limited especially when dealing with new tools/software
some areas of senior management sometimes do not want to own or actively be apart of delivery (likes to set a vision but hands off for everything else)

pros: The people were great, and the role itself was (I found) extremely exciting and enjoyable
cons: There's no routine with hours. Normal shift work could have you doing 4 days mornings then 2 days off then 5 days arvo etc. With Jetstar as long as it's a minimum 10 hour turn, you can do it. (For example - finishing at 5pm one day and starting at 3am the next.

review_title: Growing company with good opportunities for career progression.
pros: • Business is growing, and there are many opportunities to progress your career around the country in many bases.
cons:
• Migrating contracts from casual to full time is a very convoluted and lengthy process. 
• Rostering is sub-standard at times.
• Casuals can be left without any work in the quieter times of the year.

pros:
Variety, no two days are the same.
Opportunity to travel, 
Staff travel for family is an incentive however this is based on seat availability
cons:
Management have conflicting goals, hard to work with.
Micro managed.
Unreasonable overtime.
No flexibility
No freedom to grow, no training provided.
Work you to the bone, high turn over.
Staff are not motivated.
You are a number.
Hierarchy and pecking order predominant.

pros: Perfect job if you enjoy working outdoors and having close interaction with aircraft. Ping Pong in the lunch is also an attraction for many.
cons: Plenty of downtime ensures the days are long and boring. Not very challenging or rewarding. Two aircraft in fleet so not much variety.

review_title: Many opportunities for people who enjoy a busy, collaborative and somewhat chaotic environment
pros: Great people. Not overly bureaucratic or corporate (yet). Hard working, high pressure but forgiving of mistakes made the first time.
cons: Not strong on structured training or learning

pros: Great crew that we work with, exciting work environment, fast paced, challenging job, everyday is different
cons: Long days on your feet, tiring and always on show. Need to be professional at all times and not get offended easily by angry passengers

pros: Interesting projects, awesome people and team members, awesome perks
cons: No defined career path (esp. if you are coming from consulting, your expectation should be that you need to actively look for new roles to be promoted). Fixed portion of compensation slightly below industry standard

pros: Friendly working environment with helpful colleagues.
cons: Not the best mentor or training will be given, which explains the high turnover of talents.

pros: Dynamic working environment, fun people to work with.
cons: No thanks for putting in overtime, working holidays for no extra incentive pay. Missed out on Christmas with my family for 8 of the 11 years I was employed. Harassed if you take sick leave, no  opportunity to move up though the ranks of management - the prefer Crew to stay front line and advance direct entry staff instead.

pros: I've been working with skilled pilots and flight attendants, enjoying flights with those fantastic members.
cons: Too many night shifts, economically unstable with so many LCCs in Japan. But getting growing with expanding routes.

pros: Friendly working environment, Provides all necessary professional training ,  Allows to grow within the company.
cons: Most of the staff are sub contracted through KORR & ALG, No company benefits to such employees.

pros:
Great team work
Collaboration extended across different Jetstar branded airlines
cons: HK operation license application rejected by the HK government

pros: the work culture is great, plenty of opportunities to grow your level of skill
cons: geographical mobility required can take a toll on family life

pros: Dynamic and fast paced
cons: No loyalty or very little support due uncontrolled growth

pros: A great atmosphere, fantastic product and exciting company.
cons: Low cost carrier mean budgets are tight and there is not a lot spent on frills.

cons: Can be difficult stakeholder management in that work is done with other cultures

pros: customer focused people; good support from colleagues
